reasoning: The critique targets a specific pivot: that many bounded (universal-value) views are “approximately linear in practice” because humanity’s marginal impact is tiny relative to a much larger universe with abundant other value-bearing civilizations. That pivot supports one of the essay’s main routes from boundedness → linearity → fussiness, but it is not the only route (the essay also argues fussiness from unbounded linearity, from moral-fragility/multiplicative-factor considerations, and from bounded difference-making views, including separate aggregation). So centrality is moderate rather than high. On the attacked pivot itself, the objection is fairly strong: it correctly notes that the linearization claim is contingent on empirical premises (size of the universe beyond the observable region, prevalence of alien moral patients/civilizations, and the comparative magnitude of their value), and offers plausible counter-scenarios (rare life / Great Filter ahead) under which concavity might matter at human-relevant scales, potentially making some bounded views genuinely more easygoing. However, it doesn’t establish that those counter-scenarios are likely, nor that bounded concavity would in fact be easygoing once other sources of fussiness in the essay are included; so it weakens rather than refutes. The critique is clear, focused on one issue, and contains little filler.
title: The bounded-to-fussy inference relies on uncertain cosmology and alien-abundance assumptions
